name: North Vietnam
description: Home to Vietnam's ancient capital Hanoi, the spectacular limestone seascapes of Ha Long Bay, and the emerald rice terraces of the northern highlands, North Vietnam is where the country's thousand-year history and breathtaking natural landscapes converge.
overview: North Vietnam encompasses the Red River Delta, the dramatic karst landscapes of the northeast, and the cultural heartland that has shaped Vietnamese identity for over a millennium. From Hanoi's centuries-old Old Quarter and French colonial boulevards to the UNESCO-listed limestone pillars of Ha Long Bay rising from emerald waters, and the otherworldly river valleys of Ninh Binh, the north offers an unrivaled combination of history, culture, and natural grandeur. The region experiences four distinct seasons, with cool winters that set it apart from the tropical south, and an autumn that bathes everything in golden light.

topExperiences.title: Cruise Ha Long Bay
topExperiences.description: Sail among nearly 2,000 limestone karsts and islands on an overnight junk boat, kayaking through hidden grottoes and watching the sunrise over one of the world's most iconic seascapes.

topExperiences.title: Explore Hanoi's Old Quarter
topExperiences.description: Wander the 36 ancient trading streets, savor legendary street food from tiny plastic stools, and sip egg coffee in hidden upstairs cafes overlooking Hoan Kiem Lake.

topExperiences.title: Boat through Trang An
topExperiences.description: Glide by rowboat through river caves and past towering limestone cliffs in the UNESCO-listed Trang An Landscape Complex, often called Ha Long Bay on land.

topExperiences.title: Visit the Temple of Literature
topExperiences.description: Walk through Vietnam's first national university, founded in 1070, with its tranquil courtyards, ancient stone stele, and centuries of scholarly heritage.

name: Central Vietnam
description: A narrow coastal strip where imperial history meets pristine beaches, Central Vietnam is home to three UNESCO World Heritage Sites, the ancient trading port of Hoi An, the imperial citadel of Hue, and the modern coastal city of Da Nang.
highlights: Golden Bridge at Ba Na Hills
overview: Central Vietnam is the cultural backbone of the nation, stretching along a narrow coastal strip between the Truong Son mountain range and the South China Sea. This region bore witness to centuries of dynastic rule from the Nguyen Dynasty capital of Hue, saw the rise and fall of the ancient Champa Kingdom, and served as a critical theater during the Vietnam War. Today, it offers travelers an extraordinary concentration of heritage sites: the Imperial Citadel of Hue with its royal tombs along the Perfume River, the perfectly preserved Japanese-Chinese-Vietnamese trading port of Hoi An glowing with silk lanterns at dusk, and the ancient Cham sanctuary of My Son hidden in a jungle valley. Between these cultural treasures, Da Nang has emerged as a modern beach city with world-class resorts and the Instagram-famous Golden Bridge at Ba Na Hills.

topExperiences.title: Walk Hoi An's Ancient Town at Night
topExperiences.description: Watch hundreds of silk lanterns illuminate the Thu Bon River at dusk, then release your own floating lantern and explore the car-free streets of this UNESCO trading port.

topExperiences.title: Tour the Imperial Citadel of Hue
topExperiences.description: Explore the massive walled fortress that served as the seat of the Nguyen Dynasty for 143 years, including the Forbidden Purple City and ornate royal tombs along the Perfume River.

topExperiences.title: Cross the Golden Bridge at Ba Na Hills
topExperiences.description: Walk across the iconic bridge held aloft by giant stone hands high above the forested hills near Da Nang, with panoramic views stretching to the coast.

topExperiences.title: Taste Central Vietnamese Cuisine
topExperiences.description: Sample Hue's fiery royal cuisine, Hoi An's unique cao lau noodles and white rose dumplings, and Da Nang's fresh seafood along My Khe Beach.

name: South Vietnam
description: The economic powerhouse of Vietnam, the south pulses with the relentless energy of Ho Chi Minh City, offers sobering war history at Cu Chi Tunnels, and transitions into the lush waterways of the Mekong Delta where life revolves around the river.
overview: South Vietnam centers on Ho Chi Minh City (still called Saigon by locals), a sprawling metropolis of over 10 million people that serves as the country's commercial and cultural engine. The city's French colonial landmarks, sobering war museums, and legendary street food scene sit alongside gleaming skyscrapers, rooftop bars, and a nightlife that rivals Bangkok. Just outside the city, the Cu Chi Tunnels offer a visceral connection to the Vietnam War, while the surrounding countryside transitions into the vast rice paddies and fruit orchards of the Mekong Delta. The south enjoys a tropical climate with two distinct seasons -- dry and wet -- and a cuisine characterized by sweeter, bolder flavors than the north, reflecting influences from Chinese, Khmer, and French culinary traditions.

topExperiences.title: Explore Ho Chi Minh City's War History
topExperiences.description: Visit the War Remnants Museum, the Reunification Palace, and the Cu Chi Tunnels for a profound understanding of the conflict that shaped modern Vietnam.

topExperiences.title: Street Food Tour in Saigon
topExperiences.description: Navigate the city's buzzing alleys and market stalls for com tam (broken rice), banh mi, hu tieu, and an endless array of dishes from dawn to well past midnight.

topExperiences.title: Rooftop Cocktails at Sunset
topExperiences.description: Sip craft cocktails above the glittering Saigon skyline from world-class rooftop bars like the Saigon Saigon Bar at the Caravelle or Chill Skybar.

topExperiences.title: Day Trip to Cu Chi Tunnels
topExperiences.description: Crawl through the vast underground network that Viet Cong fighters used during the war, an engineering marvel stretching over 250 kilometers beneath the jungle floor.

name: Central Highlands
description: Vietnam's cool mountain interior offers a refreshing escape from the tropical coast, with misty pine forests, cascading waterfalls, world-class coffee plantations, and the charming French colonial hill station of Da Lat perched at 1,500 meters.
overview: The Central Highlands (Tay Nguyen) is Vietnam's elevated interior plateau, a world apart from the coastal lowlands both in climate and culture. Rising from 500 to over 2,000 meters, this region of rolling hills, volcanic red soil, pine forests, and cascading waterfalls was once the domain of dozens of ethnic minority groups whose stilt houses and gong culture are recognized by UNESCO. The French established Da Lat as a highland retreat in the early 1900s, and the city retains its colonial charm with Art Deco villas, flower gardens, and year-round spring-like temperatures. The region is also the heartland of Vietnam's coffee industry -- the country is the world's second-largest coffee producer -- and the fertile volcanic soil supports vast plantations of robusta and arabica beans, along with tea, silk, vegetables, and flowers that supply much of the nation.

topExperiences.title: Tour Da Lat's Coffee Scene
topExperiences.description: Visit artisan roasters and hillside plantations to taste single-origin Vietnamese coffee, from traditional robusta to world-class arabica grown at altitude.

topExperiences.title: Chase Waterfalls
topExperiences.description: Discover the highlands' spectacular waterfalls including Elephant Falls, Datanla Falls (with an alpine coaster ride down), Pongour Falls, and the remote Dambri Falls.

topExperiences.title: Explore the Crazy House
topExperiences.description: Wander through Hang Nga Guesthouse, an avant-garde architectural fantasy of organic shapes, treehouse rooms, and surreal tunnels designed by architect Dang Viet Nga.

topExperiences.title: Canyoning Adventures
topExperiences.description: Rappel down waterfalls, cliff jump into natural pools, and zip-line through the jungle canopy on an adrenaline-fueled canyoning tour in the Da Lat highlands.

name: Northwest Vietnam
description: Vietnam's most rugged and remote frontier, the northwest is a land of towering mountain passes, cascading rice terraces sculpted over centuries by ethnic minority communities, and some of the most spectacular trekking in all of Southeast Asia.
overview: Northwest Vietnam is the country's mountainous frontier, where the Hoang Lien Son range -- home to Fansipan, Indochina's highest peak at 3,143 meters -- descends into deep river valleys carved by the Red and Black Rivers. This is Vietnam at its most dramatic and least developed, a region of serpentine mountain passes, terraced rice paddies that glow emerald green in summer and golden in harvest season, and remote villages where Hmong, Dao, Tay, and Thai ethnic minorities maintain centuries-old traditions of weaving, farming, and communal life. Sapa is the most accessible gateway, now connected to Hanoi by expressway and cable car to Fansipan's summit, but the true adventure lies further afield: the legendary Ha Giang Loop, considered one of the world's greatest motorcycle journeys, winds through the Dong Van Karst Plateau Geopark along the Chinese border, past vertiginous cliffs, hidden valleys, and ethnic markets that feel unchanged by time.

topExperiences.title: Trek the Sapa Rice Terraces
topExperiences.description: Hike through the sculpted hillside terraces of Muong Hoa Valley with a local Hmong or Dao guide, staying overnight in traditional homestays in remote villages.

topExperiences.title: Ride the Ha Giang Loop
topExperiences.description: Spend 3-4 days on the epic motorbike route through the Dong Van Karst Plateau, crossing Ma Pi Leng Pass and discovering some of the most dramatic landscapes in Asia.

topExperiences.title: Summit Fansipan
topExperiences.description: Reach the roof of Indochina either by a challenging 2-day trek through cloud forest or via the record-breaking cable car for panoramic views above the clouds.

topExperiences.title: Visit Bac Ha Sunday Market
topExperiences.description: Experience the weekly gathering where Flower Hmong, Phu La, and other ethnic groups converge in a riot of color to trade livestock, textiles, and local produce.

name: Mekong Delta
description: Known as Vietnam's rice bowl, the Mekong Delta is a vast labyrinth of rivers, swamps, and islands where life unfolds on the water -- from floating markets piled high with tropical fruit to sampan rides through coconut palm-lined canals.
overview: The Mekong Delta (Dong Bang Song Cuu Long, meaning 'Nine Dragon River Delta') is where the mighty Mekong River fans out into nine tributaries before emptying into the South China Sea, creating one of the most productive agricultural regions on earth. This flat, water-soaked landscape of rice paddies, fruit orchards, fish farms, and mangrove forests feeds much of Vietnam and exports rice worldwide. Life here revolves around the water: families live in houses on stilts, children paddle to school in sampans, and commerce happens at colorful floating markets where boats are piled high with pineapples, dragon fruit, pomelo, and rambutan. Can Tho, the region's largest city, serves as the gateway to the famous Cai Rang floating market, while smaller towns like My Tho and Ben Tre offer intimate canal tours through coconut palm-lined waterways. The delta's cuisine is distinctly southern -- sweeter, spicier, and featuring an abundance of fresh river fish, tropical fruits, and coconut in every form imaginable.

topExperiences.title: Dawn at Cai Rang Floating Market
topExperiences.description: Rise before dawn to join the largest floating market in the delta, where hundreds of boats converge to trade produce, and vendors hang samples from tall poles so buyers can spot their goods from afar.

topExperiences.title: Sampan Through Coconut Canals
topExperiences.description: Glide through narrow, palm-shaded waterways in a traditional sampan in Ben Tre, visiting coconut candy workshops, bee farms, and fruit orchards along the way.

topExperiences.title: Cycle Through Rice Paddies
topExperiences.description: Rent a bicycle and ride along the elevated paths between endless rice paddies, stopping at village markets, roadside noodle stalls, and ancient pagodas.

topExperiences.title: Taste Tropical Fruits at the Source
topExperiences.description: Visit riverside orchards to sample exotic fruits straight from the tree -- mangosteen, rambutan, longan, dragon fruit, and durian -- in the region that grows most of Vietnam's fruit supply.
